awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial funding for the Brookings Conference on Economic Activity and the accompanying conference volume, the Brookings Papers on Economic Activity. The conference is designed to bring together economic scientists to focus on the scientific analysis of economic policy issues. These issues include the changing labor market, financial institutions, global economic policy, heath care, data improvement, inequality, and long run economic growth. The papers presented at the conference are available online to the public. They develop empirical analysis, employ a wide range of research methods, and focus on real world problems that affect the US economy, including the future of growth and productivity in the U.S. and abroad, challenges facing the labor market, improving economic data, and scientific examination of the effects of economic policies on trade, financial markets, health, taxes, energy, and regulation. The award promotes the national interest by improving the quality of the economics used in making policy decisions, and provides better evidence for policies that contribute to the competitiveness of the U.S. economy.

The BPEA conferences are marked by a high degree of interaction among the organizers, researchers, discussants, and attendees. Each researcher invited to present engages in an intensive process of three rounds of review, criticism, discussion and editing. BPEA encourages scientists to apply the best knowledge of the profession to pressing policy issues and uses policy concerns to point the profession's way toward new science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Brookings Papers on Economic Activity (BPEA) is a semi-annual academic conference and journal that pairs rigorous research on a broad range of macroeconomic issues with policy analysis to address the most urgent economic challenges of the day. Working drafts of BPEA papers are presented and discussed at conferences held twice each year, and the final versions of the papers and comments, along with summaries of the general discussions, are published in the journal several months later. BPEA is a long-time flagship project of the Economic Studies program at the Brookings Institution. 

From September 2018 to August 2023, BPEA hosted 11 conferences at which 74 papers, 111 discussion comments, and six thematic panels were presented. The BPEA content produced under this project has contributed to the existing research and policymaking discourse on enhancing economic opportunity and upward mobility, increasing economic growth, and understanding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. All 2018-2022 issues have been published. The Spring 2023 issue is in production.  

Although BPEA had to pause its in-person activities in the middle of this project due to the pandemic, BPEA adapted nimbly by introducing virtual event modalities and soliciting papers to address urgent economic questions raised by the pandemic. In March of 2020, BPEA announced an unprecedented summer conference in addition to the regular fall conference, and widely circulated a Call for Papers on research aimed at helping policymakers assess fiscal, monetary, and public health responses to the pandemic. The Summer 2020 papers examined the pandemic?s effects on employment and household incomes, and the Fall 2020 papers assessed the effects of Federal Reserve credit programs, the Paycheck Protection Program, and fiscal support to the U.S. economy. In particular, the Summer and Fall 2020 papers highlighted new and alternative data sources for academic research that informed public policymaking more rapidly at the early stage of the pandemic. 

BPEA returned to its traditional format featuring a variety of topics for the two 2021 conferences ? both held virtually due to the ongoing pandemic. For instance, the Fall 2021 papers examined a series of macroeconomic topics including environmental economics and policy, international trade, economic equity, COVID debt relief, and inflation. Notably, the paper, Losing the Inflation Anchor was especially timely given concerns about rising inflation as the economy recovers from the pandemic. It takes a historical and cross-country approach to inflation stability, examining the expectations of consumers, professional forecasters, and markets for inflation in the United States during the late 1960s and early 1970s (when inflation started climbing), during the early 1980s (when inflation stabilized), and during the pandemic. 

BPEA resumed in-person activities at the Fall 2022 conference, while providing our invitation-only participants with the option to join in person or virtually and livestreaming the main sessions on the Brookings website to a broader audience. The Fall 2022 papers discussed the U.S. inflation during the pandemic, the impact of Economic Impact Payments on household spending, the rise of remote work, the effect of dollar appreciation shocks on the global economy, and measuring the U.S. fiscal capacity through discounted cash flow analysis. The conference also included a panel on shrinking the Federal Reserve balance sheet. Notably, two papers, Understanding U.S. Inflation During the COVID-19 Era and The Global Dollar Cycle were cited in the World Bank?s January 2023 Global Economic Prospects report just a few months after the conference. 

BPEA provides both the conference version and the published version of each paper on the Brookings website. Data/programs for replication are posted along with published papers. BPEA also created additional educational and promotional material to share the economists? insights with the public. Starting with the Summer 2020 conference, BPEA opened conference proceedings to the public, by livestreaming the conference and posting recordings on the Brookings website. We produced a news-article style policy summary for each paper that highlights its key findings and potential policy impact. We also launched a podcast series, Brookings Podcast on Economic Activity, at the Fall 2022 conference, which aims to showcase BPEA scholars and to promote the depth and breadth of BPEA research. Notably, within three months after the Spring 2023 conference, the episode on the paper, Where Are the Missing Workers? had reached 1,128 downloads; and the episode on the paper, Is the Global Economy Deglobalizing? And If So, Why? And What Is Next? had been downloaded 1,186 times. All these materials are available on the Brookings website to anyone within or outside of the economics community who wish to learn or teach about economic theories and/or implications of specific economic policies.


Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Janice Eberly
